3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms as used in this
chapter, shall be construed according to the definitions given below:
ACT: The Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-1. et seq.\ as
amended from time to time.
ALCOHOL: Ethyl alcohol, hydrated oxide of ethyl, or spirits of wine, whiskey,
rum, brandy, gin, or any other distilled spirits including dilutions and
mixtures thereof from whatever source or by whatever process produced.
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: As defined in the Illinois liquor control act of 1934 1 , as
amended, and as may be hereinafter amended. For the purposes of this Chapter,
“alcoholic liquor” also includes any liquor confectionary. No license fee
provided for in this Chapter shall apply to wine intended for use and used by
any church or religious organization for sacramental or ceremonial purposes,
provided that such wine shall be purchased from a licensed manufacturer or
importing distributor under State law.
BEER: A beverage obtained by alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or
concoction of barley, or other grain, salt and hops in water, and includes
among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like.
CLUB: As defined in the Illinois liquor control act of 1934 2 , as amended, and
as may be hereinafter amended.
CORKAGE LICENSE: A Class H liquor license for a corkage charge establishment,
which license authorizes the establishment to allow patrons of the
establishment to bring onto, be served and consume on the licensed premises
alcoholic beverages not purchased at the licensed premises, and which license
is sometimes known as a “Bring Your Own Bottle (“
HOTEL: Every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and
held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and consumed
and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and
guests, whether transient, permanent or residential, in which twenty (20) or
more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations for such guests and having
one or more public dining rooms where meals are served to such guests, such
sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building
or buildings in connection therewith and such building or buildings, structure
or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room
equipment and capacity.
LICENSE or LIQUOR LICENSE: A retail liquor dealer’s license issued by the
Village of Lake Villa pursuant to this Chapter.
LICENSE YEAR: May 1 through April 30 of the next year, or any portion thereof
ending on the following April 30.
LICENSED PREMISES: Every building or other structure within which said
alcoholic beverages are licensed to be served, dispensed, sold, or consumed,
including any licensed outdoor area and/or any sidewalk café or other outdoor
private use area.
LICENSEE: Any person holding a license under the provisions of this chapter.
LIQUOR CONFECTIONARY: Alcohol infused candy.
LIQUOR CONTROL ACT OF 1934: The Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS
5/1-1. et seq.), as amended from time to time, sometimes referred to in this
Chapter as the “Act”.
LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSIONER: The mayor of the village of Lake Villa.
ORIGINAL PACKAGE: A bottle, flask, jug, can, barrel, keg, or other receptacle
or container, whatsoever, used, corked or capped, sealed and labeled by the
manufacturer of alcoholic liquor, to contain and convey any alcoholic liquor,
except as otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Illinois liquor control
act of 1934.
PARTNERSHIP: A general or limited partnership.
PERSON: A firm, association, authority, organization, partnership, company,
corporation, or any other legal entity, or an individual person.
POSSESS OR POSSESSION: To be within the physical control of a person or within
the area of a person's reasonably expected physical control (i.e., in their
constructive possession), but for the purposes of this chapter, "possession"
shall not include the act of lawfully serving of alcoholic liquor to one or
more customers at tables on the licensed premises by an employee of a licensee
of a class A, B, C, E, or G license issued pursuant to this chapter in the
course of their employment if such employee meets the age, employee training,
and supervision requirements of this chapter.
POWDERED ALCOHOL: For purposes of this Chapter, “powdered alcohol” (also
sometimes referred to as “alcohol without liquid”) means any powder or
crystalline substance containing alcohol, as defined in section 1-3.01 of the
Illinois Liquor Control Act, produced for human consumption.
POWDERED ALCOHOL DEVICES: A device designed, manufactured, marketed or used for
the purpose of mixing powdered alcohol with oxygen, air or another gas to
produce a mist or vapor for inhalation or snorting for other than therapeutic
purposes. It shall not include medical devices such as inhalers, nebulizers,
atomizers or other devices being used to dispense a prescribed medication to
the holder of such prescription for therapeutic purposes.
RENEWAL LICENSE: Each subsequent license after the initial license applied for
by and/or issued to an applicant for a specific class of license pursuant to
this Chapter.
RENEWAL LICENSE FEE: Or any other term of similar import, means and refers to
the license fee specified in this Chapter for the class of license for which an
application has been filed and/or for which a license has been issued.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to
the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals actually are
served and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being
provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and
capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees
to prepare, cook, and serve suitable food for its guests. A “meal” for this
purpose means any food and/or beverage that is or may be served for or as part
of breakfast, lunch, brunch, or dinner. A coffee shop may be considered a
“restaurant” if it serves meals.
RETAIL SALE: The sale for use or consumption, and not for resale.
SPIRITS: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed
with water or other substance in solution, which includes brandy, rum, whiskey,
gin, or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended or
otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances.
THERAPEUTIC PURPOSES: Where prescribed or recommended by a physician or other
healthcare provider
UNDERAGE PERSON: Any individual less than twenty one (21) years of age.
VILLAGE: The Village of Lake Villa, an Illinois municipal corporation in Lake
County, Illinois.
WINE: Any alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural
contents of fruits, or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages
when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits.
(Ord. 80-4-1, 4-23-1980; amd. Ord. 92-6-2, 6-24-1992; Ord. 2006-09-02, 9-13-
2006, eff. 1-1-2007; Ord. 2007-03-02, 3-14-2007; Ord. 2018-11-02, 11-14-2018;
Ord. 2020-06-01, 6-1-2020; Ord. 2023-09-01, 9-5-2023; Ord. 2025-05-03, 5-19-
2025)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
2 2. 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
3-8-2: LICENSING REGULATIONS AND PROCEDURES: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Compliance Required; Display of License:
      1.   Compliance Required: Each holder of a license issued by the Village
pursuant to this Chapter is and shall be required to comply with the
regulations set forth in this Chapter, all other applicable provisions of the
Village of Lake Villa Village Code, and all other applicable Village, county,
state, and federal regulations related thereto.
      2.   Display of License: It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale
at retail in the Village any alcoholic liquor without having first received
from the Village a retail liquor dealer’s license (“license”), or in violation
of the terms of such license. Every licensee shall cause his such license, or
licenses, to be framed and hung in plain view in a conspicuous place on the
licensed premises.
   B.   License Application Procedure: An applicant for any license from the
Village shall submit to the Mayor an application for liquor license in a form
approved by the Mayor from time to time and available through the Village Clerk
and completed in full in writing by the Applicant, verified by oath or
affidavit.
   Applications for licenses required by this Chapter shall be submitted to the
Mayor and filed with the Village Clerk, in writing, signed by the applicant, if
an individual, or by a duly authorized agent thereof, if a corporation, limited
liability company, partnership, limited partnership, or other entity, verified
by oath or affidavit. All applications shall be accompanied by the payment of
required non-refundable application and license fee in the amount as specified
from time to time in Section
3-8-5 of this Chapter, which shall be paid to the Village by the applicant at
the time the application is submitted to the Mayor. Each application for a
renewal license shall be accompanied by the payment of a nonrefimdable
application fee of the amount as specified from time to time in Section
3-8-5 of this Chapter.
   Applications for licenses may be submitted to the Village by e-mail, but
such applications shall nonetheless contain all required information,
including, but not limited to, an e-mail address of the respective applicant
(s), and in any event, each applicant shall be required to supplement their
respective application(s) from time to time whenever their respective e-mail
address or any other contact information changes during the application process
and throughout the license year. Each application shall contain the following
statements and information:
      1.   The name, age, and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual, in the case of a partnership, the names, ages and addresses of the
persons entitled to a share in the profits thereof, and in the case of a
corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or limited partnership,
the objects for which organized, the names and addresses of the officers and
directors, manager, and registered agent, and of any stockholder or
stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%) of the stock
of such corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or limited
partnership. Notwithstanding anything contained in this Chapter to the
contrary, if the stock of the applicant corporation is traded on a nationally
recognized securities market, the Village may elect to forgo the background
check(s) and fingerprinting of the officers, directors, stockholders, managers,
members, and/or partners owning more than five percent (5%) of the stock of
such corporation, limited liability company, partnership, or limited
partnership, if the manager of the proposed licensee and the premises to be
licensed would otherwise qualify for a license issued pursuant to this Chapter.
      2.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and, if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
      3.   The character of business of the applicant and, in case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed; the articles of incorporation
and any amendments thereto.
      4.   The length of time said applicant has been in the business of that
character or. in the case of a corporation, the date when the charter was
issued.
      5.   The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time the
application is made.
      6.   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license.
      7.   A statement whether the applicant has made an application for a
similar or other license on the premises other than    those described in the
application and the disposition of such application.
      8.   A statement that neither the applicant nor any other person
identified in the application has ever been convicted of a felony or is
disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in
this Code, laws of the State or the other ordinances of the Village.
      9.   Whether a previous license by a State or subdivision thereof, or by
the federal government, has been revoked and the reason therefor.
      10.   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of
the State or of the United States or any ordinance of the Village in the
conduct of his place of business.
      11.   A statement listing each and every occupation or business with
which the applicant and any other person identified in the application has been
associated in any capacity for fifteen (15) years prior to the filing of said
application.
      12.   A statement listing each and every arrest of the applicant and any
other person identified in the application, other than arrests for traffic
offenses, giving the place and date of arrest, the charge and the final
disposition of the charge.
      13.   Fingerprints of all the fingers of each hand of the applicant and
of any other person identified in the application, taken by personnel of the
Village.
      14.   A statement of whether the applicant has ever filed bankruptcy
proceedings and, if so, the date and place of said filing.
      15.   A statement of whether there has ever been issued to the applicant
a stamp relative to a Federal tax on wages and, if so, the date and places
where said stamp was held by the applicant and a statement of the purposes for
which held.
      16.   Referral Of Application; Investigation; Recommendation: The Mayor
shall cause a copy of each application to be forwarded promptly to each Village
Trustee and to the Chief of Police of the Village. The Chief of Police shall
investigate the applicant to determine the accuracy of the information provided
in the application and shall provide to the Corporate Authorities a report of
such investigation, which shall include a recommendation of whether he finds
the applicant qualified to hold a license pursuant to the provisions of this
Chapter.
      17   Waiting Period Before License Issuance: No license shall be issued
until at least thirty (30) days from the date of submitting said application to
the Village; provided, however, the waiting period as to an amended application
filed pursuant to Section
3-8-2(F) of this Chapter for a proposed change of location for the Licensed
Premises may be waived or reduced in length by the Mayor.
   C.   Ineligible Persons: No liquor license shall be issued to:
      1.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the
community in which he resides.
      2.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal or
State law, unless the Local Liquor Control Commissioner determines that such
person has been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust after
considering matters set forth in such person’s application and the Local Liquor
Control Commissioner’s investigation. The burden of proof of sufficient
rehabilitation shall be on the applicant.
      3.   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a
house of ill fame.
      4.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
      5.   A person whose license issued under this Chapter and/or under the
State Act has been revoked for cause.
      6.   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
      7.   A partnership, if any general or limited partner thereof owning more
than five percent (5%) of the aggregate interest in such partnership would not
be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason.
      8.   A corporation or limited liability company (“LLC”), if any officer,
manager, epdirector. or member thereof, or any stockholder or stockholders
owning in the aggregate five percent (5%) of the stock of such corporation, or
more than five percent (5%) of such LLC, would not be eligible to receive a
license hereunder for any reason other than citizenship. Notwithstanding
anything contained in this Chapter to the contrary, if the stock of the
applicant corporation is traded on a nationally recognized securities market,
the Village may elect to forego the background check(s) and fingerprinting of
the officers, directors, and stockholders owning more than five percent (5%) of
the stock of such corporation, or more than five percent (5%) of such LLC, if
the manager of the proposed licensee and the premises to be licensed would
otherwise qualify for a license issued pursuant to this Chapter.
      9.   A corporation or an LLC, unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or
unless it is a foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois
Business Corporation Act of 1983 to transact business in Illinois.
      10.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
      11.   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or
State law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor or
has forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such
violation.
      12.   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a
license is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for
which the license is to be issued.
      13.   Any law enforcing public official, including the Mayor or any
member of the Village Board of Trustees, and no such official shall be
interested directly in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic
liquor, except a license may be granted to any member of the Village Board of
Trustees in relation to premises that are located within the Village of Lake
Villa subject to the jurisdiction of that official if: a) the sale of alcoholic
liquor pursuant to the license is incidental to the selling of food, b) the
issuance of a State of Illinois license is approved by the Illinois Liquor
Control Commission, c) the issuance of the license is in accordance with all
applicable local ordinances in effect where the premises are located, and d)
the official granted a license shall not vote on any alcoholic liquor issues
pending before the Board of Trustees.
      14.   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be
operated by the licensee.
      15.   A person who has been convicted of a any local, state, or federal
gambling offense.
      16.   A person or entity to whom a federal wagering stamp has been issued
by the federal government.
      17.   A criminal conviction of a corporation is not grounds for the
denial, suspension, or revocation of a license applied for or held by the
corporation if the criminal conviction was not the result of a violation of any
Federal or State law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of
alcoholic liquor, the offense that led to the conviction did not result in any
financial gain to the corporation, and the corporation has terminated its
relationship with each director, officer, employee, or controlling shareholder
whose actions directly contributed to the conviction of the corporation. The
Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall determine if all provisions of this
subsection have been met before any action on the corporation’s license
application is initiated.
      18.   A person who at the time of the original application and/or any
application for the renewal of any license issued hereunder (other than a Class
F license) has not either completed the BASSET program as required in Section
3-8-8 of this Chapter or has not employed a manager who has completed the
BASSET training program as required in said Section
3-8-8 of this Chapter.
   D.   Term: Except as otherwise expressly provided in this Chapter, a liquor
license issued pursuant to this Chapter shall expire on April 30 next following
its issuance. Liquor licenses shall state thereon the class of license issued,
the names of the licensees and the addresses and description of the licensed
premises as well as the dates of their issuance and expiration.
   E.   Privilege Limitations, Renewal: A license shall be purely a personal
privilege, and except as otherwise expressly provided in this Chapter, shall be
good for not to exceed one year after issuance, unless sooner surrendered,
abandoned, or revoked as in this Chapter provided, and shall not constitute
property, nor shall it be subject to attachment, garnishment or execution, nor
shall it be alienable or transferable, voluntarily or involuntarily, or subject
to being encumbered or hypothecated. Such license shall cease if any material
information contained in the application on file for the current license
relative to the identity or qualification of the applicant is in any respect no
longer accurate, or if the licensee is a person or entity no longer entitled to
hold a license as specified in Section
3-8-2(C) of this Chapter. Each licensee shall have a continuing obligation to
disclose any change or anticipated change in the information contained in the
application for his current license by the filing from time to time of an
amended application or applications as necessary for this purpose. Such license
shall also cease upon the death of the licensee and shall not descend by the
laws of testate or intestate devolution; provided, that executors or
administrators of the estate of any deceased licensee, and the trustee of any
insolvent or bankrupt licensee, which such estate consists in part of alcoholic
liquor, may continue the business of the sale or manufacture of alcoholic
liquor under the order of the appropriate court, and may exercise the
privileges of the deceased or insolvent or bankrupt licensee after the death of
such decedent, or such insolvency or bankruptcy, until the expiration of such
license but not longer than six (6) months after the death, bankruptcy or
insolvency of such licensee.
   Any licensee may renew his license at the expiration thereof, provided such
licensee has submitted a renewal application, is then qualified to receive a
such license, the licensee has paid the required license renewal fee, and the
premises for which such renewal license is sought are suitable for such
purpose; and provided further that the renewal privilege herein provided for
shall not be construed as a vested right which shall in any case prevent the
Mayor and Board of Trustees from decreasing the number of licenses to be issued
within its jurisdiction.
   All liquor licensees seeking a renewal must submit a newly updated
application and/or amended application at least sixty (60) days in advance of
the expiration of the current license on April 30 of each year.
   F.   Regulations Relative to the Retail Sale of Alcoholic Liquor; Location
Restriction Restrictions;
      1.   A retail liquor dealer’s license issued hereunder shall permit the
sale of alcoholic liquor only on the premises described in the application and
in the license issued for such premises. Such location may be changed or
modified only upon written authorization to make such change issued by the
Mayor, but in order to obtain such approval, the licensee shall file with the
Mayor an amended application and a statement under oath which shall show that
the proposed new location is a proper one for the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor under the Act and the ordinances of the Village.
      2.   Proximity to Certain Uses: No license shall be issued for the sale
at retail of any alcoholic liquor within one hundred feet (100') of any church,
school, other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home for the
aged or indigent persons, or for veterans, their spouses or children, or any
military or naval station; provided that this prohibition shall not apply to
hotels offering restaurant service, regularly organized clubs, or to
restaurants, food shops or other places where the sale of alcoholic liquors is
not the principal business carried on.
      3.   Visibility of Interior; Lighting: (a) No premises upon which the
sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises is licensed, other
than as a restaurant hotel, club, or any bowling establishment, shall be
permitted to have at any time any screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or
thing on such premises which shall obstruct, obscure and/or present a clear
view of the entirety of each room or other space of such premises from any
entrance to such room or other space; (b) no booth, screen, partition, or other
obstruction nor any arrangement of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or
about the interior of such premises which shall at any time obstruct, obscure
and/or prevent a clear view of the entirety of each room or other space from
any entrance to such room or other space and/or through any window or other
opening from any street, road, or sidewalk at all times; and (c) no booth,
screen partition, or other obstruction, nor any arrangements of lights or
lighting shall be permitted in or about the interior of the licensed premises
which shall prevent a full view of the entirety of such premises from the
street, road, or sidewalk; (d) all rooms and other spaces where liquor is sold
for consumption on the premises shall be continuously lighted during business
hours by natural light or by artificial white light so that all parts of the
premises shall be clearly visible from any entrance to such room or other
space. In case the view into or onto any such licensed premises required by the
foregoing provisions shall be willfully obscured by the licensee or willfully
permitted by the licensee to be obscured or in any manner obstructed in any
type of licensed establishment, then such licensee shall be subject to
revocation of his license in the manner herein provided. In order to enforce
the provisions of this Section, the Mayor shall have the right to cause the
inspection of the licensed establishment and/or to require the filing with him
or her of plans, drawings and photographs showing the licensee’s remediation of
any violation of this subsection and the clearance of the view of the entirety
of such premises as required above.
      4.   Nothing in this Chapter shall prohibit the issuance of a license to
a church or private school to sell at retail and/or serve alcoholic liquor if
pursuant to a Class F liquor license any such sales are limited to periods when
groups are assembled on the premises solely for the promotion of some common
object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors.
      5.   Sanitary Conditions:
         a.   Premises: All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor or for the storage of such liquor for sale shall be kept in a clean and
sanitary condition in full compliance with the ordinances regulating the
condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human
consumption and the regulations of the Lake County Board of Health. Periodic
inspections will be conducted as deemed necessary, and the inspection form to
be used for such purpose shall be on file with the Village Clerk.
         b.   Employees: All of the regulations in the Village ordinances
relating to health and sanitation of employees involved in food preparation,
service, and sales shall apply to all employees in any premises used for the
retail sale and service of alcoholic liquor.
      6   .Fire Safety: All premises used for the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor and/or for the storage of such liquor for sale shall be operated in
compliance with all applicable fire safety code regulations of the Village,
including but not limited to the ICC International Fire Code. 2012. and/or any
subsequent fire safety regulations that may be adopted by the Village from time
to time. Periodic inspections of the licensed premises will be conducted as
deemed necessary by the Village and the inspection form to be used for such
purpose shall be on file with the Village Clerk. If a licensee fails to comply
with any and all fire safety regulations or inspections, then such licensee
shall be subject to suspension and/or revocation of his license in the manner
herein provided.
      7   . Building and Zoning Regulation Compliance: All premises used for
the retail sale of alcoholic liquor or for the storage of such liquor for sale
shall be operated in compliance with all applicable building and zoning
regulations of the Village as they may be amended or adopted from time to time.
Period inspections of the licensed premises will be conducted as deemed
necessary by the Village and the inspection form to be used for such purpose
shall be on file with the Village Clerk. If a licensee fails to comply with any
and all applicable building and zoning regulations or inspections, then such
licensee shall be subject to suspension and/or revocation of his license in the
manner herein provided.
   G.    Duplicate Licenses, Fees: In the event of the loss or destruction of a
license issued pursuant to this Chapter, the Mayor, upon written application
stating such fact and accompanied by the required fee, shall issue a duplicate
of such license. The non-refundable fee for the issuance of a duplicate license
shall be as specified from time to time in Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code.
   H.   Record Of Licenses: The Mayor shall act as the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner and shall keep or cause to be kept a complete record of all such
licenses issued by him and shall furnish the Village Clerk, Village Treasurer
and Chief of Police each with a copy thereof. Upon the issuance of any new
license, or the revocation of any old license, the Mayor shall give written
notice of such action to each of these officers within forty eight (48) hours
of such action. In the capacity of Liquor Control Commissioner, the Mayor shall
have the following powers, functions, and duties with respect to licenses as
provided in the Act (235 ILCS 5/4-4):
      1.   To grant, suspend for not more than thirty (30) days, and/or to
revoke for cause all Village liquor licenses issued to persons for premises
within the Village;
      2.   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any
time upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the
provisions of this Chapter or any rules or regulations adopted by the Liquor
Control Commissioner have been or are being violated, and at such time to
examine said premises of said licenses in connection therewith;
      3.   To notify the Secretary of State and the Office of the Illinois
Attorney General where a club incorporated under the laws of the State of
Illinois or a foreign corporation functioning as a club in the State of
Illinois has sold or offered for sale at retail alcoholic liquors without the
required Village liquor license;
      4.   To receive complaint(s) from any citizen within the Village that any
of the provisions of this Chapter, or any rules or regulations adopted pursuant
hereto, have been or are being violated and to act upon such complaint(s) in
the manner hereinafter provided;
      5.   To receive Village liquor license fees and pay the same forthwith to
the Village;
      6.   To levy fines in accordance with Section 7-5 of the Act (235 ILCS 5/
7-5); and
      7.   To have such other powers relating to liquor control as may be
granted to him from time to time by this Village Code, by the Act, and/or by
other Illinois statutes.
   I.   Active Operation Of Business: The holder of any liquor license who does
not actively operate the place of business for which the license was issued for
a period in excess of thirty (30) days shall be considered to have abandoned
said license and it shall be void.
   J.   Right to Appeal: Any applicant aggrieved by a decision of the Mayor,
acting as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, shall have the right to appeal
such decision to the Illinois Liquor Control Commission as and to the extent
provided by Illinois Statutes, as amended from time to time, provided, however,
any such appeal to the Illinois Liquor Control Commission shall not be a de
novo review, but rather, shall be based upon the record made before the Local
Liquor Commissioner of the Village pursuant to the Act  (235 ILCS 5/7-9). (Ord.
2007-03-02, 3-14-2007; amd. Ord. 2023-09-01, 9-5-2023; Ord. 2024-12-03, 12-2-
2024)
3-8-3: LICENSE CLASSIFICATIONS:
Retail liquor dealer licenses issued hereunder shall be and are hereby divided
into the following classes:
   A.   Class A license, which shall authorize the retail sale on the premises
described of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises described, except
as otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Act.
   B.   Class B license, which shall authorize the sale on the premises of
package beer and wine only. No on site consumption of alcoholic liquor is
permitted, except as otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of Act.
   C.   Class C license, which shall authorize the retail sale on the premises
described of wine and beer for consumption on the premises, except as otherwise
permitted by section 6-33 of the Act.
   D.   Class D license, which shall authorize the retail sale on the premises
described of alcoholic liquor in original packages, but not for consumption on
the premises where sold.
   E.   Class E license, which shall be issued to clubs and associations
organized as not for profit organizations, which has been in existence for at
least two (2) years and which shall authorize the retail sale on the premises
described therein of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the premises
described, except as otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Act.
   F.   Class F license, which shall be issued by the Board of Trustees to a
not-for-profit, church, or governmental entity for special events, which shall
authorize the retail sale on the premises described of alcoholic liquor for
consumption on the premises described; said permit shall be issued for a set
number of days with a cost of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day for said permit.
   G.   A Class G license shall authorize the sale at retail and serving of
alcoholic liquor for consumption within an outdoor area of the licensed
premises, provided such sale and serving is accessory to the main purpose of
the serving of meals and/or the seating of customers on such outdoor premises.
      1.   A Class G license shall only be issued to a holder of a then current
and valid Class A, C, E or F license.
      2.   Definition: As used in this subsection, “outdoor premises” shall
mean:
         a.   An outdoor area which is in the vicinity of a building which
contains the indoor portion of the licensed premises of a holder of a current
Class A, C, E or F liquor license; and
         b.   Such outdoor area shall not exceed six thousand (6,000) square
feet in area. Any point within such area on private property shall not be more
than one hundred fifty feet (150') from any point of the main building which
contains the indoor portion of the licensed premises.
      3.   Hours Of Sale:
         a.   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale at
retail any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the outdoor premises of a holder
of a Class G license except during the respective periods permitted for the
sale of alcoholic liquor for each specified day of the week, which are as
follows:
 
Monday through Thursday 11:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.
Friday                  9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Saturday                9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Sunday                  9:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.
Or for a Class E or F license, during those hours each day of the week as
specified in its respective license.
 
         b.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, a Class G license shall not
authorize retail liquor sales except at those respective times authorized by
the respective Class A or by the respective Class C license to which it
relates.
      4.   Effective Term: The effective term of any Class G liquor license
shall be for the respective license year which coincides with the license year
of the Class A, C, E, or F license which is required to be held by a Class G
licensee, the term of which shall, in any event, expire on April 30 next
following its issuance; provided, however, that during the entire term that a
Class G license is in effect, the holder of a Class G license must, at all
times during such term, also be the holder of a current and valid Class A, C,
E, or F license. Accordingly, if, for any reason whatsoever, such Class A, C,
E, or F license is revoked, suspended or terminated during the term of the
Class G license, the Class G license, shall also be automatically and
immediately revoked, suspended or terminated, as the case may be, without any
further action by the Village.
      5.   Additional Restrictions: The following shall be applicable with
respect to the outdoor premises:
         a.   The outdoor premises used for a Class G license, shall be owned
or leased, and operated by the same person or entity to whom the Class A, C, E,
or F license has been issued.
         b.   At all times, the outdoor premises shall be used in conjunction
with the operation of any indoor premises used for the related Class A, C, E,
or F license.
         c.   The outdoor premises shall not block, in any way whatsoever, any
entrance to or exit from the building(s) used for the licensed premises.
         d.   The outdoor premises shall be secured in such a manner so as to
allow safe ingress to and egress from the area of the outdoor premises.
         e.   The maximum number of persons allowed at any time in such outdoor
premises shall not exceed the permitted occupancy of said outdoor premises as
determined by the Village.
         f.   Live entertainment shall not be permitted on the outdoor premises
except when specifically approved in advance by the Mayor and Board of
Trustees. Any other type of entertainment and/or music provided shall not
exceed sixty (60) decibels in noise level as measured from the property line
between the property on which the outdoor premises is located and any
properties in the vicinity.
         g.   Any artificial lighting on the outdoor premises shall be
sufficient to provide for the safety and security of all persons using such
area, but shall not be at such a level so as to create a nuisance or to inhibit
the normal use and enjoyment of other properties in the vicinity.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, as measured from any point, the artificial
lighting shall not exceed one-tenth (0.1) foot-candle anywhere within or on any
boundary of the outdoor premises.
         h.   The entire operation and use of the outdoor premises shall be
carried on so as not to pose any risk to the public health, safety, or welfare,
or to create a nuisance and/or to interfere with the use and enjoyment of other
properties in the vicinity.
         i.   The detailed management plans for use of any outdoor premises
shall be submitted to the Village Administrator for his prior written approval,
and such detailed management plans shall be in compliance with the Illinois
Department of Public Health and/or Lake County Board of Health rules,
regulations, toolkits, and/or guidelines relative to protecting the public
health.
   H.   Class H license shall be a corkage license, sometimes known as a “BYOB
License”, issued to a commercial establishment where food, goods, and/or
services are sold and the serving of alcoholic beverages is incidental to the
primary business operation of the licensed premises, which establishment
charges a corkage fee for the opening and/or serving on the licensed premises
of any alcoholic beverage(s) (hereinafter, a “corkage charge establishment”)
and which license authorizes such establishment to allow patrons of the corkage
charge establishment to bring onto, be served, and consume on the licensed
premises alcoholic beverages not purchased at the licensed premises, subject to
the following conditions:
      1.   A Class H license shall be required to be obtained by a corkage
charge establishment to authorize patrons of such establishment to bring onto,
be served, and/or to consume on the licensed premises alcoholic beverages that
were not purchased at the licensed premises.
      2.   Alcoholic beverages may only be brought onto the premises of a
corkage charge establishment holding a current, valid Class H license by
patrons of such establishment who concurrently order and are served food which
is consumed on the licensed premises, and/or who purchase other goods and/or
services from the licensee.
      3.   Every container of alcoholic beverage(s) brought by a patron onto
the premises of a corkage charge establishment holding a Class H license must
be sealed and/or otherwise unopened and shall only be opened by the authorized
personnel of the licensee, and it shall be unlawful for any patron to either
bring onto such licensed premises or leave such licensed premises with an open
or a partially consumed container of such alcoholic beverage, except as
otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Act.
      4.   Limited Individual Servings: Only authorized personnel of a holder
of a Class H liquor license shall be permitted to open and/or uncork and serve
to a patron of the corkage charge establishment who is at least twenty-one (21)
years of age such limited amounts as provided for herein of any alcoholic
beverage(s) brought onto the licensed premises by a patron consisting of not
more than two (2) individual services (each not to exceed twelve (12) ounces
per customer per calendar day).
      5.   Any alcoholic beverage may only be opened or uncorked and served on
the premises of a corkage charge establishment holding a Class H license by the
authorized personnel of the licensee during the regular business hours of the
establishment.
      6.   The bringing of, possession of, and/or consumption of any alcoholic
beverage by any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years of age on any
premises holding a Class H license issued by the Village is prohibited.
      7.   A person or entity holding a Class H license may, at his, her or its
discretion, charge “corkage fees” for the opening and/or serving of alcoholic
beverage(s) on the licensed premises.
      8.   All of the other provisions under this chapter shall be applicable
to corkage licenses.
      9.   The holder of a Class H liquor license shall only allow the serving
of alcoholic beverage(s) if and when such alcoholic beverage is brought onto
the licensed premises by a customer of the corkage charge establishment.
   I.   A Class I license shall be granted to a not-for-profit, church, or
governmental entity and shall authorize the sale at retail and serving of
alcoholic liquor for consumption only on the licensed premises (except as
otherwise permitted by section 6-33 of the Act) for an outside special event as
authorized by the Board of Trustees of the Village administratively approved by
the Local Liquor Control Commissioner.
      1.   Additional License Required: A Class I license shall only be issued
to a holder of a then current and valid Class A, C, E or F license.
      2.   Fee: The required nonrefundable fee for each Class I license, which
shall be issued administratively by the Local Liquor Control Commissioner, for
outside consumption on the licensed premises for a Village- authorized special
event shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per day. Each day of a special event
shall require a separate license.
      3.   General Rules And Regulations For All Class I Liquor Licenses:
         a.   All Class I licenses require approval by the Local Liquor Control
Commissioner of the Village at least seven (7) calendar days in advance of the
proposed special event. The Village encourages applicants to submit the
application for the Class I liquor license at least fourteen (14) calendar days
in advance of a proposed special event.
         b.   The hours of operation for any Class I liquor license shall not
exceed eight (8) hours in a twenty four-hour period and each Class I license,
when issued, shall specify the hours of operation and if not, the hours of such
Class I license shall be limited to the hours from nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. to
nine o’clock (9:00) P.M.
         c.   A license holder shall be limited to a maximum of four (4) Class
I liquor licenses in a calendar year.
         d.   Any special event authorized by the Village by the issuance of a
Class I license shall be held entirely and only on the licensed premises owned
or leased, and operated by the same person to whom the Class A, C, E, or F
license has been issued.
         e.   The artificial lighting of the outdoor premises shall be
sufficient to provide for the safety and security of all persons using such
area, but shall not be at such a level so as to create a nuisance or to inhibit
the normal use and enjoyment of properties in the vicinity. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, as measured from any point, the artificial lighting shall not exceed
one-tenth (0.1) foot-candle both anywhere within and also on the boundaries of
the outdoor premises.
         f.   The entire operation of any special event shall be carried on so
as not to pose any risk to the public health, safety, or welfare or to create a
nuisance or to interfere with the use and enjoyment of other properties in the
vicinity.
         g.   Prior to the event, the applicant shall provide to the Village in
writing all required approval(s) from the Lake County Health Department as may
be applicable for such special event.
         h.   A Class I liquor license for an outdoor special event and the
holder of such a liquor license shall be subject to all of the same terms and
conditions as are applicable to a Class J license.
      4.   Review And Approval: The Local Liquor Control Commissioner shall
review and approve plans submitted by the applicant(s) for the following prior
to and as a condition for the issuance of a Class I liquor license:
         a.   Location and layout of the proposed special event.
         b.   Number of persons permitted to attend the proposed special event
at one time.
         c.   Special event security and security screening, if necessary.
         d.   Location and number of outdoor liquor dispensaries.
         e.   Types of liquor (beer, wine, other alcoholic liquor) to be served
and consumed outside.
         f.   Type of music to be permitted, time and duration, and the maximum
noise level as measured from the property line between the property on which
the outdoor premises is located and any adjoining property.
         g.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may reduce the maximum
hours permitted and/or alter the permitted time for the special event if the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner determines the hours of the special event
will have a negative impact on the Village.
         h.   The Local Liquor Control Commissioner may use his or her
judgement to reduce the number of permitted Class I liquor licenses in a
calendar year, if the Local Liquor Control Commissioner concluded that the
issuance of additional Class I liquor licenses will have a detrimental impact
on the Village.
      5.   Board Of Trustees Approval: A Class I liquor license which is not in
conformance with regulations in this subsection shall not be approved by the
Local Liquor Control Commissioner but may be approved by the Board of Trustees
of the Village but only if the Board of Trustees, in its sole discretion,
determines that the proposed special event will not have a detrimental impact
on the Village.
      6.   Off-Premises Consumption And Sale: The Board of Trustees of the
Village may approve a special event license for the consumption and sale of
liquor off the licensed premises, provided the applicant shall first obtain all
permits, licenses, and/or approvals required by the Illinois Liquor Control
Commission.
   J.   A Class J license:
      1.   Shall authorize the holder of a Class A, C, E, or F liquor license,
which is also the holder of a permit for a sidewalk café or such other outdoor
private use area, to sell and serve alcoholic liquor for consumption out of
doors in a designated and authorized outdoor area of a Village sidewalk, other
Village right-of-way, or other Village property incidental to the sale of food
items in such an outdoor area pursuant to the applicable regulations of this
Village Code and of the Lake County Board of Health.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or offer for sale at
retail any alcoholic liquor for consumption on the outdoor premises of a
sidewalk café except during the following specified times and days of the week:
 
Monday through Thursday 11:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.
Friday                  9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Saturday                9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Sunday                  9:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.
 
      3.   The effective term of any Class J liquor license shall be for the
respective license year which coincides with the license year of the Class A,
C, E, or F license which must also be held by the Class J licensee, the term of
which shall, in any event, expire on April 30 next following its issuance;
provided, however, that during the entire term that a Class J license is in
effect, the holder of a Class J license must, at all times during such term,
also be the holder of a current, valid Class A, C, E, or F license. If, for any
reason, such Class A , C, E, or F license is revoked, suspended or terminated
during the term of the Class J license, the Class J license, shall also be
automatically and immediately revoked, suspended or terminated, as the case may
be, without any further action by the Village.
(Ord. 2006-09-02, 9-13-2006, eff. 1-1-2007; amd. Ord. 2012-01-01, 1-25-2012;
Ord. 2018-11-02, 11-14-2018; Ord. 2020-06-01, 6-1-2020; Ord. 2023-09-01, 9-5-
2023; Ord. 2025-05-03, 5-19-2025)
