1-18-1 of this Village Code. In addition to the fine herein set forth, such
person shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due and unpaid.
(Ord. 2010-02-06, 2-10-2010, eff. 4-1-2010; amd. Ord. 2024-12-03, 12-2-2024)
CHAPTER 20
VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS
SECTION:
3-20-1: Definitions
3-20-2: Annual User Fee Required For Any Video Gaming Terminal
3-20-3: Video Gaming Terminals Permitted
3-20-4: Village Policy Relative To Video Gaming Cafes
3-20-1: DEFINITIONS:
The term "video gaming terminal" shall be as defined in the Illinois Video
Gaming Act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40, as amended from time to time
(the "Video Gaming Act"). (Ord. 2012-08-02, 8-8-2012)
3-20-2: ANNUAL USER FEE REQUIRED FOR ANY VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL:
   A.   Video Gaming Terminal User Fee: An annual user fee for each calendar
year is hereby imposed upon each video gaming terminal located and/or operated
in the Village.
   B.   Village Database Maintained: Each operator of a video gaming terminal
within the Village shall provide to the Village the following required
information for entry into a database which shall be maintained by the Village
relative thereto, which information shall include but not be limited to: (i)
the name of the operator of the premises, (ii) the telephone number and email
address of the operator, (iii) the address where the video gaming terminals are
or will be located, (iv) the number of video gaming terminals on the subject
premises, (v) the serial number of each video gaming terminal on the subject
premises, (vi) the brand name of the video gaming terminal, (vii) the type of
video gaming terminal, and (viii) a copy of the current state license issued to
the operator for each such video gaming terminal.
   C.   Payment of Annual User Fee Required:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any video gaming
terminal within the Village for use by any other person unless the annual user
fee thereon pursuant to this chapter has been paid for the current year. It
shall be unlawful for any person to install, keep, maintain or use, or permit
the installation, keeping, maintenance, or use upon any premises within the
Village of any video gaming terminal upon which such annual user fee has not
been paid.
      2.   After providing to the Village the required information for the
Village database and a copy of the operator's current state license as set
forth in paragraph B hereof and paying the annual user fee required for each
video gaming terminal, the operator of the premises where such video gaming
terminal(s) is or are located shall be authorized to use and operate each such
video gaming terminal for such calendar year.
   D.   User Fee Specified: Such non-refundable annual user fee for each video
gaming terminal for any calendar year, or portion thereof, before January 1,
2022 shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per terminal for each calendar year.
For each calendar year, or portion thereof, beginning on or after January 1,
2022, a non- refundable annual user fee shall be as specified from time to time
in Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code. (Ord. 2012-08-02, 8-8-2012; amd. Ord. 2022-02-02,
2-8-2022; Ord. 2024-12-03, 12-2-2024)
3-20-3: VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS PERMITTED:
Notwithstanding anything contained in this Code to the contrary, video gaming
terminals shall be permitted within the Village but only in compliance with
this chapter and the Video Gaming Act. (Ord. 2012-08-02, 8-8-2012)
3-20-4: VILLAGE POLICY RELATIVE TO VIDEO GAMING CAFES:
   A.   Effective August 23, 2017, it is the policy of the Corporate
Authorities of the Village to not create any new liquor licenses for any
additional video gaming cafes in the Village, because the proliferation of such
establishments within the Village will discourage new restaurants from being
established within the Village and will thereby reduce the growth in the
Village's commercial tax base, except under the exceptions identified in
subsection B of this section. For purposes of this section and the Village
policy set forth herein, a video gaming cafe is defined as an establishment
whose primary or a major focus is video gaming, and the service of alcoholic
beverages and/or food is secondary to the video gaming operation. The following
factors shall be considered by the Corporate Authorities of the Village when
determining if a proposed establishment is a video gaming cafe:
      1.   The layout and design of the establishment;
      2.   The preparation and variety of food and beverages offered;
      3.   The creation and operation of a commercial kitchen on the premises
where gaming is situated or a partnership with an establishment that operates a
commercial kitchen;
      4.   The proposed number of video gaming machines relative to the
proposed customer seating capacity of the establishment must be at least ten
(10) customer seats to one video gaming terminal;
      5.   The square footage of space devoted to video gaming relative to the
amount of space which will be devoted to other activities must be at least four
(4) times as much space for non-gaming activities in comparison to the space
which will be devoted to video gaming;
      6.   The sources of proposed or actual revenue derived from an
establishment;
      7.   Whether the establishment is proposed to be marketed as a gaming
establishment and whether the establishment will have a gambling theme;
      8.   The number of employees of the establishment and their respective
proposed functions; and
      9.   Any other factors as determined relevant by the Corporate
Authorities of the Village and/or by the Village of Lake Villa Liquor
Commissioner.
   B.   Notwithstanding the foregoing, the Corporate Authorities of the
Village, in their sole discretion, may, however, consider creating a liquor
license for a video gaming cafe if one or more of the following conditions are
present:
      1.   The presence of a complementary nearby establishment that serves a
variety of food and beverages where another video gaming cafe is not in close
proximity; or
      2.   The proximity of the video gaming cafe to another establishment with
video gaming terminals; or
      3.   Whether the video gaming cafe offers a unique business opportunity
not then present in the Village. (Ord. 2017-08-02, 8-23-2017)
CHAPTER 21
SIDEWALK CAFES
SECTION:
3-21-1: Sidewalk Cafes; Provisions
3-21-1: SIDEWALK CAFES; PROVISIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: No person or entity shall place tables, chairs,
equipment, or other portable appurtenances upon any public sidewalk within the
Village or upon any Village road, street, or alley or upon other Village
property, or for an outdoor use on private property for the purpose of the sale
and serving of food and beverages to customers for on-site consumption without
having first obtained a permit from the Village for such outdoor use.
   B.   Applicant With Liquor License: If an applicant for such permit is a
holder of a current and valid Class A or Class C liquor license which
authorizes the sale and serving of alcoholic beverages at its place of
business, such applicant shall also be required to obtain from the Village a
Class J liquor license for a location on Village property, or a Class G liquor
license for an outdoor use location on private property prior to and as a
condition precedent to its obtaining a permit from the Village for such outdoor
use.
   C.   Applicant Without Liquor License: In the event an applicant for a
permit for any such outdoor use does not hold a current and valid Class A or a
Class C liquor license and a current and valid Class J or Class G liquor
license, no alcoholic beverages may be served in the outdoor premises.
   D.   Required Fees:
   1.   Application Fee: The non-refundable application fee for a permit for a
sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use area or for such an outdoor use area
on private property shall be as specified from time to time in Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code.
   2.   Permit Fee For A Sidewalk Cafe, Or For An Outdoor Private Use Area, Or
For An Outdoor Area On Private Property: The annual fee for a permit for a
sidewalk cafe or for an outdoor private use area, or for such an outdoor use
area on private property, and/or any renewal thereof, shall be as specified
from time to time in Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code for each permit year, or portion thereof. This
shall be a fixed fee for each permit year, or portion thereof, and shall not be
prorated.
      3.   Waiver Or Reduction Of Fee(s): Notwithstanding the foregoing fee
provisions, the Mayor of the Village, or his or her designee, may waive or
reduce such fee if he or she, in his or her sole discretion, finds that exigent
circumstances provide good cause for such relief.
   E.   Term: A permit for such an outdoor use shall only be valid from April 1
through November 30 annually. Each holder of such a permit shall be required to
submit to the Village an annual application, together with any required fee(s),
for renewal thereof.
   F.   Application: Any person or entity desiring to obtain a permit for such
an outdoor use from the Village shall submit to the Village an application for
such a permit in such form as the Village may prescribe. Such application shall
be accompanied by such documentation that the Village may require to
appropriately consider and investigate the application as well as the payment
of the permit fee for such application, including, but not limited to, the
following:
      1.   Plat, Plan Or Drawing: A copy of a plat, plan, or drawing
indicating, to scale, the public sidewalk or other outdoor public area or such
private outdoor area that the applicant is seeking permission to occupy and the
location of furniture, equipment, and any other articles of the applicant which
are proposed to be utilized in connection with such outdoor use and intended to
occupy the public sidewalk, road, street, or alley, or on other Village
property or for an outdoor use on private property for which a permit is being
requested.
      2.   Insurance: Proof of insurance, including the dram shop insurance
coverage as required by Illinois Statutes if the applicant sells and serves
alcoholic beverages anywhere on the outdoor licensed premises, with a
Certificate of Insurance which shall also comply with the following
requirements:
         a.   The Certificate of Insurance shall evidence commercial general
liability insurance with limits of not less than one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and in the aggregate as a combined single limit,
for personal injury, bodily injury, and property damage liability.
         b.   The Certificate of Insurance shall also evidence liquor liability
in the amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per
occurrence and in the aggregate as a combined single limit, as well as dram
shop coverage for the licensed premises, including the Village premises in the
required statutory amount(s) if the applicant holds any current and valid Class
J or Class G liquor license or has applied for one.
         c.   The applicant's insurance coverage shall be primary and non-
contributory as respects the Village of Lake Villa and its officers, officials,
employees, agents and volunteers for any liability arising directly or
indirectly from the operations of a sidewalk cafe and/or from the Village
permit issued for such outdoor use.
         d.   Any insurance or self-insurance maintained by the Village of Lake
Villa and/or on behalf of its officers, officials, employees, agents and/or
volunteers shall be in excess of the applicant's insurance and shall not
contribute to it.
         e.   The "Description" section of all Certificates of Insurance shall
name the Village of Lake Villa, its elected and appointed officials, officers,
employees, and agents as additional insureds in regard to the establishment and
operation of any such sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use area, or for
an outdoor area on private property and relative to the Village permit issued
for such outdoor use.
      3.   Ownership Or Lease: Proof of ownership or a copy of the lease and
other satisfactory evidence of the applicant's ownership and/or leasehold
occupancy of any outdoor area on private property and the applicant’s
proprietorship of the business which will operate such outdoor area which is
proposed.
      4.   Indemnification Agreement: As a condition precedent to the Village's
issuance of a permit for a sidewalk cafe or outdoor private use area or for an
outdoor area on private property, the applicant shall agree to indemnify,
defend, and hold harmless the Village of Lake Villa, its elected and appointed
officials, officers, agents, and employees from any and all claims, actions,
injuries, or damages of every kind and description which may accrue to or be
suffered by any person by reason of or related to the establishment and/or
operation of any sidewalk cafe or outdoor private use area on any Village
property or any outdoor area on private property and shall be required to
execute an indemnification agreement substantially in the following form:
         INDEMNIFICATION AND
         HOLD HARMLESS AGREEMENT
      
         RE: PERMIT FOR SIDEWALK CAFE OR OUTDOOR PRIVATE USE AREA OR OUTDOOR
AREA ON PRIVATE PROPERTY
         PERMIT NUMBER:          
         NAME OF APPLICANT:    
         ADDRESS OF APPLICANT’S BUSINESS:    
                                                     , Lake Villa, Illinois
         The undersigned, for himself or herself individually and for the
aforesaid Applicant(s), represents and warrants to the Village of Lake Villa
that the undersigned is a duly authorized representative of the Applicant(s)
authorized to execute this Indemnification and Hold Harmless Agreement (the
"Agreement") on behalf of the Applicant(s) and agrees to and shall, to the
greatest extent permitted by law, indemnify and hold harmless and defend the
Village of Lake Villa (the "Village"), its elected and appointed officials,
officers, employees, and agents ("Village indemnitees") from and against any
and all liability or loss from personal injury or property damage resulting
from or arising out of, in whole or in part, the Permit issued or to be issued
by the Village to the aforesaid Applicant(s) for the purpose of establishing
and operating a Sidewalk Cafe or other Outdoor Private Use Area or an Outdoor
Area on Private Property. The Applicant(s) shall and does hereby further waive
any claims that the Applicant(s) may have against the Village with respect to
consequential, incidental, or special damages, however caused, based on the
theory of liability.
         Nothing set forth in this Agreement shall be deemed a waiver by the
Village of any defenses or immunities that are or would be otherwise available
to the Village or any Village parties under the provisions of the Illinois
Local Government and Governmental Employees Tort Immunity Act, or that are
otherwise available to local governments and their Corporate Authorities,
officers, employees, agents and volunteers under the common law of the State of
Illinois or the United States of America. The provisions of this Section shall
survive the expiration or earlier termination of this Agreement or renewal
thereof.
         The undersigned Applicant(s) understand and agree that the Permit for
a Sidewalk Cafe or other Outdoor Private Use Area or for an Outdoor Area on
Private Property for which the Applicant(s) are applying is a temporary
license, terminable at will by the Village at any time for any reason or merely
for the convenience of the Village.
         The terms and conditions of this Agreement shall survive the
expiration, termination, suspension, and/or revocation of the Permit granted by
the Village.
         APPLICANT(S):    
         By:       
         Its duly authorized agent
         Print Name:    
         Title:    
         Date:       
   G.   Approval: The approval of an application for a permit for a sidewalk
cafe or for an outdoor private use area or for an outdoor area on private
property may be conditioned upon certain modifications being made to the
applicant’s request which are determined by the Village Administrator to be
necessary to mitigate, reduce, and/or avoid any risk to the public health,
safety, and welfare. If and when the application is approved by the Village
Administrator, such a Permit may be issued to authorize use of a public Village
sidewalk or a specified portion of a Village road, street, alley, or other
Village property and the sale and serving of food and beverages on such Village
premises or in an outdoor area on private property. Applicant(s) who knowingly
furnish false or misleading information or falsely answer any questions and/or
make any false statements in the application for such a Permit, or one who
knowingly furnishes false or misleading information to any Village official
during the application process, may have its application for such a Permit
denied, or if already issued, such Permit may be suspended or revoked, but only
after written notice to the applicant and after an opportunity to be heard has
been provided to the applicant by the Village Administrator.
   H.   Requirements: Upon issuance, a Permit for a sidewalk cafe or other
outdoor private use area, or for an outdoor area on private property shall be
subject to each of the following requirements:
      1.   All sidewalk cafes and other outdoor private use areas and outdoor
areas on private property shall be located only in the specific location
described in the approved application. Furnishings and/or other equipment of an
applicant(s) which have been approved by the Village for location on such
outdoor Village premises may not be modified or substituted without an
additional or supplemental written approval by the Village Administrator.
      2.   All areas authorized by the Village for outdoor use by an applicant
(s) shall be cordoned off in a manner approved by the Village Administrator by
the use of a temporary picket fencing or by use of stanchion poles with ropes
or plastic or metal chain. No permanently affixed fencing or stanchions shall
be allowed, except for an outdoor area on private property.
      3.   No portion of any umbrella or similar shelter located within a
sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use area or within an outdoor area on
private property, other than any support member, shall be less than six and
one- half feet (61/2') above ground level. All umbrellas must have a mobile
base.
      4.   The operation of any outdoor area as regulated by this Chapter shall
at all times comply with any and all applicable public health and safety
guidelines and/or regulations as may be issued from time to time by the
Illinois Department of Public Health, the Lake County Board of Health, the
Center for Disease Control, the Illinois Department of Commerce and Economic
Opportunity, and/or any other State or federal agency or jurisdiction.
      5.   Where emergency or exigent circumstances exist and any authorized
officer or employee of the Village gives notice to a permittee to temporarily
move from a location or suspend operations of any such sidewalk cafe or other
outdoor private use or other outdoor use area on private property, such
permittee shall immediately comply with said notice. For purposes of this
paragraph, exigent circumstances shall include, but not be limited to, a threat
of potentially dangerous or severe weather, other circumstances which may
negatively affect the public health, unusually heavy pedestrian or vehicular
traffic, the existence of any obstructions and/or encroachment(s) in the public
space at or near the location of a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use
area or other outdoor area on private property, a parade, a demonstration, or
any other such event or occurrence at or near the location of such a sidewalk
cafe or other outdoor private use area or other outdoor area on private
property, as determined by the Mayor, by the Village Administrator, by the
Chief of Police, or by any of their respective designees.
      6.   Except as otherwise expressly provided in chapter 8 of this title,
the hours of operation of any such sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use
area, or any outdoor area on private property shall be as follows:
 
Monday through Thursday 11:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.
Friday                  9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Saturday                9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Sunday                  9:00 A.M. to 10:00 P.M.
 
      7.   Any holder of a permit for any outdoor area is required to clean and
clear the area authorized by the Village for outdoor private use no later than
ten o’clock (10:00) P.M. on Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday,
and no later than twelve o’clock (12:00) midnight on Friday and Saturday,
including but not limited to disposal of any litter and/or debris deposited on,
in, or adjoining the vicinity of the outdoor area, and all of the permittee’s
equipment and items used for seating, including but not limited to umbrellas,
chairs, tables, stations, etc. within the outdoor premises authorized by the
Village for outdoor private use shall be removed or positioned in a safe manner
as close as possible to the permittee’s building on the adjacent premises until
the next day’s use.
      8.   All food and beverages may be served only in/on a container/dish
made of a product that does not easily shatter or break. Glass and/or other
easily breakable containers/dishes are prohibited on and/or within any outdoor
premises.
      9.   Tables located within the sidewalk cafe area or other outdoor
private use area, or within any outdoor area on private property shall be
cleared of all moveable items when not being used or when outside of the hours
authorized for use.
      10.   No smoking shall be allowed within the sidewalk cafe area or within
such other outdoor private use area.
      11.   Any refuse or trash containers placed upon or located within any
sidewalk cafe area or any outdoor private use area by the permittee shall be
emptied by the permittee daily. Unemptied refuse or trash containers shall not
be allowed to remain on any such sidewalk cafe area or on any outdoor private
use area after the respective times provided in this chapter for the final
daily clearing of the sidewalk cafe area or other outdoor private use area. A
permittee’s refuse or trash shall not be placed into any Village refuse or
trash container and shall be properly disposed of by the permittee in one or
more private refuse containers.
      12.   The permittee shall at all times conduct all activities within the
sidewalk cafe area or within some other outdoor private use area or other
outdoor area on private property in an orderly fashion and in such a manner as
to protect the public health, safety, and welfare.
      13.   The permittee shall comply with all applicable health, sanitation,
and safety rules and regulations relative to the sale and serving of food and/
or beverages, but alcoholic beverages may be sold and served on the sidewalk
cafe premises or on any outdoor private use area only if the permittee has a
current and valid Class J liquor license to authorize the sale and serving of
alcoholic beverages on the premises of a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private
use area.
      14.   The name of the insured shown on the permittee's Certificate of
Insurance must be the same name as the person or entity that applied for the
permit for a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use area or for an outdoor
area on private property.
      15.   The permit for a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use area,
or for an outdoor area on private property shall be displayed and kept posted
in a conspicuous place on the exterior of the business premises of the
permittee.
      16.   The following additional restrictions shall be applicable with
respect to the outdoor premises of any sidewalk cafe or any outdoor private use
area or an outdoor area on private property authorized by the Village:
         a.   The premises of a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use
area, or an outdoor area on private property shall not in any way block any
entrance to or exit from the building(s) used for the licensed premises.
         b.   The premises of a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor private use area
shall be fully enclosed in such a manner so as to prohibit ingress to and
egress from the area of the outdoor premises except through designated
entrances and exits.
         c.   The maximum number of persons allowed at any time within such a
sidewalk cafe or within such other outdoor private use area or an outdoor area
on private property shall not exceed the permitted occupancy of said area as
determined by the Village’s Building Officer.
         d.   Live entertainment shall not be permitted on the premises or any
sidewalk cafe or the premises of any other outdoor private use area or of an
outdoor area on private property except when specifically approved in advance
in writing by the Mayor and Board of Trustees. Any other type of entertainment
and/or music provided shall not exceed sixty (60) decibels in noise level as
measured from any private property in the vicinity, other than from the
property of the applicant(s).
         e.   Any artificial lighting of the premises of any sidewalk cafe or
of any other outdoor private use area or of an outdoor area on private property
shall be sufficient to provide for the safety and security of all persons using
such area, but shall not be at such a level so as to create a nuisance or to
inhibit the normal use and enjoyment on other properties in the vicinity.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, the artificial lighting shall not exceed one-
tenth (0.1) foot-candle both anywhere within and also on the boundaries of the
sidewalk cafe area or other outdoor private use area or of an outdoor area on
private property.
         f.   The entire operation and use of the premises of a sidewalk cafe
or of some other outdoor private use area or of an outdoor area on private
property shall be carried on so as to not pose any potential risk to the public
health, safety, or welfare or to create a nuisance or to interfere with the use
and enjoyment on other properties in the vicinity.
   I.   Suspension; Revocation: A permittee's failure to comply with any of the
above requirements of this chapter may result in the suspension and/or
revocation by the Mayor or by the Village Administrator of the permit issued by
the Village for such sidewalk cafe or for some other outdoor private use area
or for an outdoor area on private property. In addition, the Corporate
Authorities of the Village, the Mayor, or the Village Administrator as their
designee, may immediately terminate any license for an outdoor area issued a
permit pursuant to this chapter if the Corporate Authorities, the Mayor, or the
Village Administrator determine that such permit presents a substantial risk to
or potential negative impact upon the public health, safety, and/or welfare of
the Village or that such license is for any reason otherwise not in the best
interest of the Village.
   J.   Permit Not Assignable Or Transferable: Any permit for a sidewalk cafe
or for any other outdoor private use area or for an outdoor area on private
property issued pursuant to this section shall be a personal privilege provided
to the respective applicant and may not be transferred or alienated, whether
voluntarily or involuntarily.
   K.   Liquor License Required:
      1.   The holder of a Class A or Class C liquor license who wishes to
obtain a permit to establish and/or operate a sidewalk cafe or other outdoor
private use area or an outdoor area on private property within the Village
shall also be required to obtain and maintain a current and valid Class J
liquor license created by the Village Board of Trustees and issued by the Local
Liquor Control Commissioner prior to being authorized to sell and serve
alcoholic liquor within such outdoor premises. A permittee holding a Class J or
Class G liquor license shall comply with all of the applicable rules and
regulations set forth in chapter 8, “Liquor Regulations,” of this title, or any
other applicable provision(s) of this Code.
         a.   Any alcoholic liquor sold or served outdoor premises shall be
limited to the specific alcoholic liquor authorized by the current and valid
liquor license(s) held by a permittee.
         b.   If the holder of a permit for a sidewalk cafe or such other
outdoor private use area or outdoor area on private property holds a Class J or
Class G liquor license, neither the permittee, nor any officer, agent, or
employee of the permittee, shall sell, serve, or allow such patrons to consume
alcoholic liquor on the outdoor premises unless such patrons are located within
the authorized area thereof identified in the approved site plans.
         c.   Alcoholic liquor shall not be brought into and/or onto the
premises of a sidewalk cafe area or into or onto the premises of such other
outdoor private use area, except by the permittee or by the employees of such
permittee carrying alcoholic liquor directly between the licensed establishment
and the authorized outdoor area of such establishment, and then only if the
permittee holds a current and valid Class J or Class G liquor license and
except that a customer of a Class J or Class G Licensee may bring onto such
outdoor premises his or her own bottle of wine still with the original seal
intact for serving in accordance with the terms of a current and valid Class H
license, if one has been issued to the permittee.
         d.   Unless the permittee holds both a current and valid Class J or
Class G liquor license and a current and valid Class H liquor license, neither
a permittee, nor any officer, employee, or agent of a permittee, shall permit
alcoholic liquor to be brought by a patron or customer into and/or onto the
authorized outdoor premises from off of any licensed premises.
         e.   Alcoholic liquor shall not be removed from the outdoor premises,
unless such permittee holds a current and valid Class J or Class G liquor
license and then only when such permittee or its employees are carrying
alcoholic liquor directly between the licensed establishment and the authorized
outdoor premises or except as provided pursuant to either Section 6-28.8 or
Section 6-33 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act.
         f.   A permittee which holds a valid Class J or Class G liquor license
and its employees shall monitor the activities and movements of its patrons and
customers to ensure that alcoholic liquor is not removed from or brought into
and/or onto the outdoor premises except from the related licensed premises.
(Ord. 2018-11-02, 11-14-2018; amd. Ord. 2020-06-01, 6-1-2020; Ord. 2024-12-03,
12-2-2024)
TITLE 4
PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY
CHAPTER 1
NUISANCES
SECTION:
4-1-1: Definitions
4-1-1.1: Purpose
4-1-2: Nuisance Declared
4-1-3: Penalty
4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter and in order to carry out its provisions and
intentions, certain words, terms and phrases shall be determined to have the
meanings ascribed to them herein.
Words in the singular number include the plural, and those in the plural number
include the singular. The masculine gender includes the feminine and neuter.
DONATION BOX: A freestanding accessory structure, container, receptacle, or
similar device that is used for soliciting and collecting donations of clothing
or other salvageable personal property, provided, however, that this term
excludes any unattended donation boxes located within a secured building.
JUNK: Shall include, but is not limited to, discarded paper, cartons, boxes,
barrels, wood, plastics, metals, pieces of glass, crockery and other discarded
manufactured items.
PERSON: Any person, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company or
organization of any kind.
PROPERTY: Any real property within the village which is not a street or
highway.
STREET OR HIGHWAY: The entire width between the boundary lines of every way
publicly maintained when any part thereof is open to the use of the public for
purposes of vehicular traffic.
VEHICLE: A machine propelled by power other than human power designed to travel
along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides and transport
persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation,
automobile, truck, trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy and wagon.
VEHICLE, ABANDONED: Abandoned vehicles are vehicles located on public or
private property which are allowed to remain on public property, or on private
property without the consent of the owner, for a period of more than twenty
four (24) hours.
VEHICLE, UNLICENSED AND/OR UNREGISTERED: Any vehicle which under the laws of
the state of Illinois would be required to be licensed or registered in order
to be operated on public highways within the state and/or which under the
ordinances of the village is required to bear a current sticker unless the
vehicle shall be entirely within a fully enclosed building. (Ord. 2013-05-02,
5-22-2013; amd. Ord. 2014-08-03, 8-27-2014)
4-1-1.1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to define and abate public nuisances to prevent
detriment to the people of Lake Villa and to the property values within the
village. The nuisances defined herein are detrimental to the safety, health and
public welfare, and are deemed adverse to the conservation of property values.
(Ord. 2013-05-02, 5-22-2013)
4-1-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
The following are declared to be public nuisances when they exist upon property
within the limits of the village and are hereby prohibited:
   A.   Junk Accumulation: To cause, permit, or allow the accumulation or
storage within the village of trash, junk, and partially dismantled motor
vehicle, wrecked motor vehicle, any unlicensed or unregistered motor vehicle
which under the laws of the state would be required to be licensed or
registered in order to be operated on public highways within the state,
discarded appliances, used machinery, refuse, garbage, discarded furniture,
rubble, or other similar items or materials, whether on public or private
property, for a period in excess of thirty (30) days unless the same shall be
situated within a suitable enclosed building provided for the purpose.
   B.   Donation Boxes: Donation boxes are hereby declared to be a public
nuisance and are hereby prohibited anywhere within the village unless all of
the following conditions are met: 1) such donation box is directly related to
an existing lawful use of the property; 2) such donation box is owned and
operated by the owner of the property on which it is located; and 3) a permit
was secured for such donation box as a temporary use as required by the village
of Lake Villa zoning ordinance in advance of the installation of such donation
box.
   C.   Animals, Where Restricted: The location of farm animals in any zone
other than the applicable zone of the Lake Villa zoning ordinance 1 .
   D.   Offensive Lights: It shall be unlawful for any owner, tenant, and/or
other person having control of real estate within the village to cause, permit,
or allow any light(s) located on such real estate to illuminate onto property
owned by another person in such a manner as to be offensive to and/or interfere
with the owner(s), tenants, and/or occupants of such other property. Lighting
with an illumination level of greater than three (3) lumens on, or at any
height above, the lot line shall be considered to be offensive, and is hereby
declared to be a public nuisance and is prohibited. (Ord. 2013-05-02, 5-22-
2013)
   E.   Unregistered, Unlicensed, And Abandoned Vehicles: Unregistered,
unlicensed, and abandoned vehicles are declared a public nuisance. In addition
to all other remedies, the village shall have such further remedies to abate
such nuisances as are contained in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-201 et
seq., and 5/4-201 through and including 5/4-213 are hereby adopted by
reference.
   F.   Other Nuisances: Any and all items or activities described or declared
to be a nuisance in the Illinois Compiled Statutes, or in this code, as amended
from time to time, are likewise hereby so declared to be public nuisances
pursuant to this code. (Ord. 2014-08-03, 8-27-2014)
   G.   Control Over Other Provisions: This chapter shall control over any
other provisions of this code or of other village ordinances which are
inconsistent herewith. (Ord. 2013-05-02, 5-22-2013)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 10 of this code.
4-1-3: PENALTY:
For the purposes of this chapter, a "person" shall mean and include any
individual, corporation, association, partnership, or any other legal entity.
Any person found guilty of or liable for violating any of the terms of this
chapter shallbe subject to a mandatory fine as specified from time to time in
Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code. (Ord. 2013-05-02, 5-22-2013; amd. Ord. 2024-12-03,
12-2-2024)
CHAPTER 2
ABATEMENT OF CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES
SECTION:
4-2-1: Violation
4-2-2: Definitions
4-2-3: Fines And Other Remedies
4-2-4: Abatement Of Nuisance
4-2-5: Notification Procedure
4-2-6: Commencement Of Action; Burden Of Proof
4-2-7: Emergency Procedures For Securing Of Chronic Nuisance Properties
4-2-8: Discretionary Action
4-2-9: Exempt Conduct
4-2-1: VIOLATION:
   A.   Any certain property within the village of Lake Villa which becomes or
remains a chronic nuisance property is in violation of this chapter and subject
to its remedies.
   B.   Any responsible party, as defined herein, who permits property under
his or her ownership, possession, and/or control to be a public nuisance
property is in violation of this chapter and subject to its remedies. (Ord.
2015-08-03, 8-12-2015)
4-2-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings set forth
below:
APPLICABLE TRIBUNAL: Either the administrative adjudication system and/or code
hearing department established, maintained, and/or jointly utilized by the
village of Lake Villa or the circuit court of the 19th judicial circuit, Lake
County, Illinois, as to matters within the respective jurisdiction of such
tribunal.
CHIEF OF POLICE: The chief of police of the village of Lake Villa police
department.
CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTY: Property upon which three (3) or more of the
nuisance activities listed below have occurred during any one hundred twenty
(120) day period, as a result of any three (3) separate events, the respective
facts of which have been independently investigated by any law enforcement
agency:
   A.   "Disorderly conduct" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/26-
1;
   B.   "Unlawful use of weapons" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/24-1 et seq.;
   C.   "Mob action" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/25-1;
   D.   "Discharge of firearm" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
24-1.2 and 1.5;
   E.   "Gambling" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/28-1;
   F.   "Possession, manufacture or delivery of controlled substances" as
defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 570/401 et seq.;
   G.   "Public indecency" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-
30;
   H.   "Assault or battery or any related offense" as defined in 720 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/12-1 et seq.;
   I.   "Prostitution" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-14 et
seq.;
   J.   "Criminal damage to property" as defined in 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/21-1 et seq.;
   K.   "Possession, cultivation, manufacture or delivery of cannabis" as
defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/3 et seq.;
   L.   "Illegal consumption or possession of alcohol" as defined in 235
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-16 et seq.
   M.   "Domestic violence" means "abuse" as defined in section 103 of the
Illinois domestic violence act of 1986 by a "family or household member" as
defined in section 103 of the Illinois domestic violence act of 1986.
OWNER: Any person, entity, firm or corporation having any legal or equitable
interest in the property. Owner includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   The person, persons, entity or entities which hold record legal title
to a property.
   B.   A mortgagee of a property in whom is vested:
      1.   All or part of the legal title to the property, or
      2.   All or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to the present
use and enjoyment of the premises; or
   C.   Any tenant or other occupant who has the right or ability to control
what occurs on the property; or
   D.   The beneficiary(ies) of a land trust which holds record legal title to
a property.
PERMIT: To suffer, allow, consent to, acquiesce in, to fail to prevent, or
expressly assent or agree to the doing of an act.
PERSON: Any natural person, association, partnership, limited liability
company, or corporation capable of owning or using property in the village.
PROPERTY: Any real property, including land, which is affixed, incidental or
pertinent to land, including, but not limited to, any premises, room, house,
building or structure or separate part or portion thereof, whether permitted or
not.
RESPONSIBLE PARTY(IES): Any person or persons in actual or constructive
possession and/or control of a property, including, but not limited to, an
owner of a property, occupant of a property, and/or an owner's agent.
SEXUAL VIOLENCE: Any act of sexual assault, sexual abuse, or stalking of an
adult or minor child, including, but not limited to, nonconsensual sexual
conduct or nonconsensual sexual penetration as defined in the civil no contact
order act and the offenses of stalking, aggravated stalking, criminal sexual
assault, aggravated criminal sexual assault, predatory criminal sexual assault
of a child, criminal sexual abuse, and aggravated criminal sexual abuse as
those offenses are described in the criminal code of 2012.
VILLAGE: The village of Lake Villa, Lake County, Illinois. (Ord. 2015-08-03, 8-
12-2015)
4-2-3: FINES AND OTHER REMEDIES:
   A.   Any person who is found guilty of or liable for a violation of this
Chapter shall be subject to a mandatory fine as specified from time to time in
Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code.
   B.   Without any limitation on the foregoing, any person who is a
responsible person with respect to a chronic nuisance property shall be subject
to a mandatory fine as specified from time to time in Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code for each day such chronic nuisance property exists
or continues to exist without the implementation of a remedial plan approved by
the chief of police, provided, however, if one or more responsible persons have
been found guilty or liable by an applicable tribunal within the preceding
three hundred sixty five (365) days of any violation of this chapter, then, in
such event, the minimum fine shall be not less than as specified from time to
time in Section
1-18-1 of this Village Code.
   C.   In the event a property is a chronic nuisance property, the village,
through its village attorney or village prosecutor, may seek an order from an
applicable tribunal requiring all owner(s), occupant(s), and/or their
respective agent(s), guest(s) and invitees to temporarily or permanently cease
and desist from any or all use and/or occupancy of the property until adequate
and effective remedial steps have been taken by the one or more responsible
parties to ensure that the property in question will no longer be a chronic
nuisance property. (Ord. 2015-08-03, 8-12-2015; amd. Ord. 2024-12-03, 12-2-
2024)
4-2-4: ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE:
The village attorney or village prosecutor may prosecute such cases or assist
in the prosecution of such cases as are filed in an applicable tribunal when
the remedies sought are within the respective jurisdictions of those
adjudicatory bodies.
The village attorney or village prosecutor may commence an action in the Lake
County circuit court in order to abate or cause the abatement of any violation
(s) of this chapter and may petition the Lake County circuit court for a
temporary restraining order and/or preliminary and/or permanent injunction(s)
to enjoin any and all responsible parties from maintaining such a chronic
nuisance property. (Ord. 2015-08-03, 8-12-2015)
4-2-5: NOTIFICATION PROCEDURE:
When the chief of police receives one or more police reports documenting the
occurrence of a nuisance activity on or within a property, the chief of police
shall independently review such reports to determine whether they describe one
or more of the nuisance activities specified in section 4-2-2 of this chapter.
Upon such findings, the chief may:
   A.   Notify the responsible party(ies) in writing that the property is at
risk of becoming a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain the
following information:
      1.   The street address and a brief or full legal description of the
property sufficient for identification thereof;
      2.   A statement that the chief of police has information that the
property is at risk of becoming and/or may be a chronic nuisance property, with
a concise description of the nuisance activities that may exist or that have
occurred. The chief of police shall offer the responsible party(ies) an
opportunity to propose and implement a remedial course of action if the chief
of police determines that such proposed remedial course of action will more
likely than not abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation;
      3.   Demand that the responsible party(ies) contact the chief of police
within ten (10) days from the date of said notice to discuss the nuisance
activities and to determine what actions may be required to abate such nuisance
activities and mitigate such chronic nuisance property status.
      4.   For purposes of these notice provisions, the owner of the property
shall be determined to be the last taxpayer of record, or as otherwise
determined by such deed or other instrument of conveyance as recorded with the
Lake County recorder of deeds. Such notice shall be served on one or more of
the responsible party(ies) by either personal delivery or by mailing to one or
more of the responsible party(ies) by regular U.S. mail, postage prepaid.
Notice to the property owner shall be mailed to the taxpayer's mailing address
as shown on the last ascertainable tax bill.
   B.   If after complying with the notification procedures described herein
the chief of police receives a police report documenting the occurrence of a
third nuisance activity at or within a property and determines that the
property has become a chronic nuisance property, the chief of police, or his
designee, shall:
      1.   Notify the responsible party(ies) in writing that the property has
been determined to be a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall conform to
the following:
         a.   It shall set forth the street address and a brief or full legal
description of the property sufficient for identification of the property;
         b.   It shall include a statement that the chief of police has
determined the property to be a chronic nuisance property with a concise
description of the nuisance activities leading to his/her findings;
         c.   It shall demand that the responsible party(ies) contact the chief
of police within ten (10) days from the date of said notice to discuss the
nuisance activities and determine what remedial course of action is necessary
to abate the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation;
         d.   Service of such notice shall be made upon the responsible
parties. For purposes of these notice provisions, the owner of the property
shall be determined to be the last taxpayer of record, or as otherwise
determined by such deed or other instrument of conveyance as recorded with the
Lake County recorder of deeds. Such notice shall be served on one or more of
the responsible party(ies) by either personal delivery or by mailing to one or
more of the responsible party(ies) by regular U.S. mail, postage prepaid.
Notice to the property owner shall be mailed to the taxpayer's mailing address
as shown on the last ascertainable tax bill.
         e.   If the responsible party(ies) has or have not contacted the chief
of police within the prescribed ten (10) day time frame set forth in said
notice to discuss and determine a course of action to remediate the chronic
nuisance property, the chief of police, or his designee, is and shall be
authorized to post a copy of said notice at the property;
         f.   The failure of any person to receive notice that the property may
be a chronic nuisance property shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the
proceedings under this chapter.
      2.   If, after the chief of police, or his designee, has served the
aforesaid notification, but prior to the commencement of enforcement action by
the village before an applicable tribunal pursuant to this chapter, one or more
responsible parties enters into a written agreement with the chief of police
wherein such responsible party(ies) agree to pursue, within an agreed upon time
frame, a remedial course of action that both the responsible party(ies) and the
chief of police agree is more likely than not to abate the nuisance activities
giving rise to the violation, the chief of police may agree to postpone legal
proceedings for a period of not less than ten (10) days nor more than thirty
(30) days. If the agreed course of action does not result in the abatement of
the nuisance activity or if no agreement concerning abatement is reached within
thirty (30) days after notice was served upon the responsible party(ies), the
chief of police shall request the village attorney or the village prosecutor to
commence enforcement action before an applicable tribunal to abate the chronic
nuisance property.
      3.   Concurrent with the notification procedures set forth herein, the
chief of police shall provide to the village attorney or village prosecutor
copies of such notices, as well as any other documentation which supports
enforcement action by the village.
   C.   When a responsible party responds to the chief of police as required by
this chapter, no such responsible party(ies) shall be required to waive their
right(s) against self-incrimination or any other constitutional protections.
(Ord. 2015-08-03, 8-12-2015)
4-2-6: COMMENCEMENT OF ACTION; BURDEN OF PROOF:
In an action seeking the abatement of a chronic nuisance property, and/or
seeking to impose fines in any applicable tribunal, the village shall have the
burden of showing by preponderance of the evidence that the property is a
chronic nuisance property. (Ord. 2015-08-03, 8-12-2015)
4-2-7: EMERGENCY PROCEDURES FOR SECURING OF CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES:
   A.   In the event that it is determined that a property in the village is an
immediate threat to the public health, safety and welfare, the village may
apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for such interim relief as
determined by the circuit court to be appropriate to the circumstances. In such
an event, the village shall not be required to comply with the notification
provisions set forth in section 4-2-5 of this chapter, however, the village
will still be required to make a diligent effort to notify the responsible
party(ies) prior to any court hearing.
   B.   In the event that a court of competent jurisdiction finds the property
constitutes a "chronic nuisance property" as defined in section 4-2-2 of this
chapter, the court may order such remedies as provided by this chapter and/or
such other remedies as are available at law or in equity.
   C.   In the event that a court of competent jurisdiction authorizes the
village to physically secure a property against use or occupancy in the event
the owner and/or other responsible party fails to do so within the time
specified by the court, the village shall secure the property in question as
quickly as reasonably possible. In the event that the village is authorized to
secure the property, all costs incurred by the village to effect the securing
thereof shall be accounted for and assessed and recorded as a lien against the
property, and each of the responsible parties with respect to such property
shall be jointly and severally liable for and obligated to pay all such costs.
   D.   Any person(s) who is or are responsible for payment of the cost
incurred by the village for the securing of a chronic nuisance property shall
be personally liable for the payment thereof to the village, and the
responsible parties with respect to such property shall be jointly and
severally liable for same. (Ord. 2015-08-03, 8-12-2015)
4-2-8: DISCRETIONARY ACTION:
The provisions of this chapter are designed and intended to give discretion to
the chief of police, the village attorney, the village prosecutor, and other
village officers, employees, and/or agents, and are intended to provide tools
and mechanisms for the village to abate or to cause the abatement of chronic
nuisance properties and to help preserve the peace and order of its
neighborhoods and to protect the public health, safety and welfare. For these
reasons, the following provisions, consistent with the reservation of
discretion shall apply:
   A.   Nothing in this chapter shall create or shall be construed as creating
any rights to any private person to require action to be taken by any elected
or appointed official, employee or agent of the village.
   B.   Nothing herein is intended to give any party(ies) whose ownership,
possession, and/or tenancy of any property is disrupted by any action taken
pursuant to this chapter any claim against the village or its elected or
appointed officers, officials, employees, and agents relative to any loss of
use, occupancy, possession, and/or control of such property. (Ord. 2015-08-03,
8-12-2015)
4-2-9: EXEMPT CONDUCT:
Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, this chapter does not
apply to and shall not be interpreted or construed in such a manner so as to
penalize any tenant(s) or any landlord(s) based upon:
   A.   Contact made with police or other emergency services, if: 1) the
contact was made with the intent to prevent or respond to domestic violence or
sexual violence; 2) the intervention or emergency assistance was needed to
respond to or prevent domestic violence or sexual violence; or 3) the contact
was made by, on behalf of, or otherwise concerns an individual with a
disability and the purpose of the contact was related to that individual's
disability;
   B.   An incident or incidents of actual or threatened domestic violence or
sexual violence against a tenant, household member, or guest occurring in the
dwelling unit or on the premises; or
   C.   Any criminal activity or a local ordinance violation occurring in a
dwelling unit or on the premises that is directly related to domestic violence
or sexual violence, engaged in by a tenant, member of a tenant's household,
guest, or other party, and against a tenant, household member, guest, or other
party; or
   D.   The reporting of any emergency situation involving neither criminal
activity nor any local ordinance violation(s).
   E.   None of those activities listed in subsection A, B, C, or D of this
section shall constitute or be construed as nuisance activities. (Ord. 2015-08-
03, 8-12-2015)
CHAPTER 3
OUTDOOR BURNING REGULATED
SECTION:
4-3-1: Burning Prohibited
4-3-2: Wood Burning Regulated
4-3-1: BURNING PROHIBITED:
The outdoor burning of leaves, refuse, garbage, yard waste, or other waste
materials is prohibited. (Ord. 2008-07-02, 7-9-2008)
4-3-2: WOOD BURNING REGULATED:
Wood may be burned in a burning pit or other suitable device subject to the
following:
   A.   There shall be no burning on any public road or within ten feet (10')
of any structure or within thirty feet (30') of any lake, wetland, or
conservation area.
   B.   Each fire must be attended to by a competent person until the fire is
extinguished.
   C.   An extinguishing source, such as a functioning garden hose, must be
available at the site of the fire.
   D.   The fire shall be extinguished immediately if requested by an employee
of the village who has determined that a hazard exists due to the atmospheric
conditions, excessive smoke, high flames, or otherwise.
   E.   The person burning is responsible to ensure that the fire does not
become a nuisance. (Ord. 2001-3-3, 3-28-2001)
CHAPTER 4
DUMPING IN LAKES PROHIBITED
SECTION:

4-4-2: Depositing Property Into Water Prohibited

(Ord. 92-6-7, 6-24-1992)

stream, river, or any other navigable water, any property.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any owner of property to allow or permit any
such property to be deposited in any lake, pond, stream, river, or any other
navigable water. (Ord. 92-6-7, 6-24-1992)

paying to the Village the mandatory fine(s) as specified from time to time in

1-18-1 of this Village Code, shall make restitution to the village for all
reasonable costs incurred by it in removing, disposing, or storage of the
property, and including any attorney fees incurred by the village. (Ord. 92-6-
7, 6-24-1992; amd. Ord. 2013-07-02, 7-24-2013; Ord. 2024-12-03, 12-2-2024)

may institute any appropriate actions in law or equity. (Ord. 92-6-7, 6-24-
1992; amd. Ord. 2013-07-02, 7-24-2013)

CHAPTER 6
WATERSHED DEVELOPMENT AND SITE DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS

4-6-1: Stormwater Management Regulations; Adoption Of Lake County Watershed
Development Ordinance
4-6-2: Adoption Of Site Development Regulations
4-6-1: STORMWATER MANAGEMENT REGULATIONS; ADOPTION OF LAKE COUNTY WATERSHED
DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE:
The Lake County Watershed Development Ordinance (hereinafter referred to as the
“Watershed Development Ordinance” or as the “LCWDO”), as most recently amended
by the County of Lake on July 11, 2023, is hereby adopted by reference as if
fully set out herein and shall be and is in full force and effect within the
Village of Lake Villa, with the exception of Section 1201 “Fines”, which
Section 1201 is not adopted. Such Ordinance is found in its own compilation on
file in the Village Clerk’s Office, and a copy of said Ordinance has been on
file in the Village Clerk’s Office for a period of not less than thirty (30)
days prior to the effective date hereof. Fines applicable to the LCWDO as
adopted by this Section
4-6-1 shall be as specified from time to time in Section
1-18-1, "Fees, Charges, Deposits, Fines and Other Amounts Payable to the
Village", of the Lake Villa Village Code, as amended from time to time. (Ord.

2023; Ord. 2024-12-03, 12-2-2024)
4-6-2: ADOPTION OF SITE DEVELOPMENT REGULATIONS:
The site development regulations are hereby adopted by reference by the village
of Lake Villa, and to the extent that the site development regulations hereby
adopted are inconsistent with the Lake County watershed development ordinance
as adopted in section 4-6-1 of this chapter, said site development regulations
shall govern and prevail, except where the Lake County watershed development
ordinance mandates more restrictive provisions, in which case the Lake County
watershed development ordinance shall govern and prevail. (Ord. 2005-09-02, 9-
28-2005)
CHAPTER 7
AERATORS 1
SECTION:
4-7-1: Purpose
4-7-2: Aerators Required
4-7-3: Responsible Parties
4-7-4: Type Of Equipment
4-7-5: Exceptions
4-7-6: Compliance
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 11-2-4G11 of this code.
4-7-1: PURPOSE:
The village has determined that aerators should be installed in ponds and other
bodies of water to oxygenate the water and thereby prevent the buildup of
noxious weeds and algae, and to inhibit the breeding of mosquito larvae. (Ord.
96-7-1, 7-10-1996)
4-7-2: AERATORS REQUIRED:
Aerators shall be installed in every pond or other body of water which is wet
or designed to be wet on a year round basis in normal weather, excluding for
example drought conditions. This requirement shall apply to all existing bodies
of water, excluding Deep Lake and Cedar Lake, for which aerators are
unnecessary. (Ord. 96-7-1, 7-10-1996)
4-7-3: RESPONSIBLE PARTIES:
The owner of the pond, or the land upon which it is situated, shall be
responsible to install and properly maintain the aerator so that it is always
functional and operating. (Ord. 96-7-1, 7-10-1996)
4-7-4: TYPE OF EQUIPMENT:
The type of aerator and associated apparatuses shall be subject to the prior
review and approval of the village engineer, who shall approve equipment and
installations, which are suitable for the given body of water, and will
function as intended. (Ord. 96-7-1, 7-10-1996)
4-7-5: EXCEPTIONS:
No aerator shall be required if the village engineer determines that an aerator
is not practical or would not accomplish the intent of this chapter. (Ord. 96-
7-1, 7-10-1996)
4-7-6: COMPLIANCE:
For all existing such bodies of water, the aerators shall be installed and
fully operational within six (6) months of adoption of this chapter. For all
new bodies of water, which are created subsequent to the adoption of this
chapter, the aerator shall be installed at the time of construction of the pond
or other water storing device, such as detention or retention pond areas. (Ord.
96-7-1, 7-10-1996)
CHAPTER 8
RESTRICTIONS ON THE OUTSIDE USE OF WATER
SECTION:
4-8-1: Purpose
4-8-2: Restrictions On The Outside Use Of Water Enumerated
4-8-3: Special Permit
4-8-1: PURPOSE:
It is necessary and prudent to institute restrictions on the nonessential
outside use of water to conserve water as a valuable resource. (Ord. 2011-05-
01, 5-11-2011)
4-8-2: RESTRICTIONS ON THE OUTSIDE USE OF WATER ENUMERATED:
Lawn and garden sprinkling and all other nonessential outside use of water
shall only be permitted as follows:
   A.   Even numbered property addresses: Even numbered calendar days.
   B.   Odd numbered property addresses: Odd numbered calendar days.
   C.   All such watering and all other nonessential outside use of water is
prohibited between the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. to eight o'clock (8:
00) P.M.
   D.   All such watering and all other nonessential outside use of water is
prohibited on Sundays.
   E.   The foregoing restrictions on lawn and garden sprinkling and all other
nonessential outside use of water shall be applicable at a minimum from May 15
through September 15 of each year, and for such additional periods as may be
established by the village pursuant to subsection F of this section from time
to time.
   F.   Effective upon a specific written determination by the village board,
when conditions warrant further and more restrictive conservation measures than
the foregoing, all nonessential water use may be prohibited by the village
board. Notice of such restrictions may be provided by a press release to the
local newspapers, by posting on the village website and at the village hall,
and by temporary signage at the main entrances to the village. (Ord. 2011-05-
01, 5-11-2011)
   G.   New and replacement sprinkler systems shall be equipped with a
WaterSense labeled irrigation controller and shall be in compliance with
section 2.5(g) of the Illinois plumbing license law 1 . (Ord. 2015-09-01, 9-9-
2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 320.
4-8-3: SPECIAL PERMIT:
Upon good cause shown, a special permit may be issued for a period of fourteen
(14) consecutive days to allow watering on both even and odd numbered days.
These special permits may be obtained from the village hall during normal
business hours. The outside use of water on Sundays is still prohibited despite
the issuance of a special permit and all such outside use of water shall, in
any event, conform with subsection 4-8-2C of this chapter. (Ord. 2011-05-01, 5-
11-2011)
CHAPTER 9
PROHIBITED NOISES
SECTION:
4-9-1: Purpose
4-9-2: Construction Activities
4-9-3: Exemption
4-9-4: Special Permit
4-9-1: PURPOSE:
Construction activities generate considerable noise which detracts from the
overall quality of life and intrudes upon the peace and well being of the
general public. The intent of this chapter is to limit such activities to
reasonable hours. (Ord. 2004-07-03, 7-28-2004)
4-9-2: CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES:
It shall be unlawful to operate construction equipment such as, but not limited
to, hand tools, such as hammers or saws, power tools, backhoes, bulldozers,
jackhammers, compressors, and the like, before:
   A.   Seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on
weekdays.
   B.   Eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on
Saturdays.
   C.   Nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. on Sundays.
In the event that the construction activities are subject to a preconstruction
meeting such as for a subdivision development, then in the event of a conflict
between the terms of this chapter and those of the preconstruction meeting, the
hours of permitted construction activities established in the preconstruction
meeting shall govern. (Ord. 2004-07-03, 7-28-2004)
4-9-3: EXEMPTION:
This chapter does not apply to the activities of the village of Lake Villa
employees while performing their respective duties. (Ord. 2004-07-03, 7-28-
2004)
4-9-4: SPECIAL PERMIT:
Upon good cause shown in cases of necessity in the interest of public health
and/or safety, the building commissioner may issue a special permit, which
permit may be granted for a period not to exceed three (3) days or less while
the necessity continues, to operate construction equipment at times other than
as permitted in sections 4-9-2 and 4-9-3 of this chapter, and which permit may
be renewed for periods of three (3) days or less while the necessity continues.
(Ord. 2004-07-03, 7-28-2004)
CHAPTER 10
LAKE VILLA SMOKE FREE ILLINOIS ACT REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-10-1: Short Title
4-10-2: Findings
4-10-3: Definitions
4-10-4: Smoking In Public Places, Places Of Employment, And In Other Locations
Prohibited
4-10-5: Posting Of Signs; Removal Of Ashtrays
4-10-6: Designation Of Other Nonsmoking Areas
4-10-7: Exemptions
4-10-8: Enforcement And Penalties
4-10-9: Discrimination Prohibited
4-10-10: Effective Date
4-10-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the VILLAGE OF LAKE VILLA SMOKE
FREE ILLINOIS REGULATIONS. (Ord. 2015-03-01, 3-11-2015)
4-10-2: FINDINGS:
The corporate authorities of the village of Lake Villa find that tobacco smoke
is harmful and dangerous to human beings and a hazard to public health. The
corporate authorities of the village additionally find that the vapor, odor
and/or other byproducts produced by the use, by any means, of any alternative
nicotine product in public places and places of employment is a nuisance which
may annoy, disturb, injure and/or endanger the comfort, repose, convenience,
health, peace and/or safety of others in the presence or vicinity of a person
using an alternative nicotine product. (Ord. 2015-03-01, 3-11-2015)
4-10-3: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings
ascribed to them in this section unless different meanings are plainly
indicated by the context:
ACT: The "smoke free Illinois act", 410 Illinois Compiled Statutes 82/1 et seq.
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT: A product or device not consisting of or
containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine,
whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting,
sniffing, or by any other means. "Alternative nicotine product" excludes
cigars, cigarettes, smokeless tobacco, or other tobacco products as these terms
are defined in 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 675/1 et seq., and any product
approved by the United States food and drug administration as a nontobacco
product for sale as a tobacco cessation product, as a tobacco dependence
product, or for other medical purposes, and is being marketed and sold solely
for that approved purpose.
BAR: An establishment that is devoted to the serving of alcoholic beverages for
consumption by guests on the premises and that derives no more than ten percent
(10%) of its gross revenue from the sale of food consumed on the premises.
"Bar" includes, but is not limited to, taverns, nightclubs, cocktail lounges,
adult entertainment facilities, and cabarets.
BUSINESS: Any sole proprietorship, partnership, joint venture, corporation,
association, limited liability partnership, limited liability company, or other
business entity, whether formed for profit or nonprofit purposes.
DEPARTMENT: The Illinois department of public health.
EMPLOYEE: A person who is employed by an employer in consideration for direct
or indirect monetary wages or profits or a person who volunteers his or her
services for a nonprofit entity.
EMPLOYER: A person, business, partnership, association, or corporation,
including a municipal corporation, trust, or nonprofit entity that employs the
services of one or more individual persons.
ENCLOSED AREA: All space between a floor and a ceiling that is enclosed or
partially enclosed with: a) solid walls or windows, exclusive of doorways, or
b) solid walls with partitions and no windows, exclusive of doorways, that
extend from the floor to the ceiling, including, without limitation, lobbies
and corridors. For the purposes of this chapter, an "enclosed area" shall also
include any open air dining area, and the area within or under any tent,
canopy, trailer, and/or any other partially enclosed or partially covered
permanent or temporary structure.
ENCLOSED OR PARTIALLY ENCLOSED SPORTS ARENA: Any sports pavilion, stadium,
gymnasium, health spa, boxing arena, swimming pool, roller rink, ice rink,
bowling alley, or other similar place where members of the general public
assemble to engage in physical exercise or participate in athletic competitions
or recreational activities or to witness sports, cultural, recreational, or
other events.
GAMING EQUIPMENT OR SUPPLIES: Gaming equipment/supplies as defined in the
Illinois gaming board rules of the Illinois administrative code.
GAMING FACILITY: An establishment utilized primarily for the purposes of gaming
and where gaming equipment or supplies are operated for the purposes of
accruing business revenue.
HEALTHCARE FACILITY: An office or institution providing care or treatment of
diseases, whether physical, mental, or emotional, or other medical,
physiological, or psychological conditions, including, but not limited to,
hospitals, rehabilitation hospitals, weight control clinics, nursing homes,
homes for the aging or chronically ill, laboratories, and offices of surgeons,
chiropractors, physical therapists, physicians, dentists, and all specialists
within these professions. "Healthcare facility" includes all waiting rooms,
hallways, private rooms, semiprivate rooms, and wards within healthcare
facilities.
OPEN AIR DINING AREA: A seating area open to the air that is accessory to a
restaurant, hotel, cafeteria, club or other enclosed public place engaged in
purveying commercial food or beverage service where members of the public,
members or guests are invited to sit and receive food or beverage service.
PLACE OF EMPLOYMENT: Any workplace or area under the control of a public or
private employer within the village that employees are required to enter,
leave, or pass through during the course of employment, including, but not
limited to, entrances and exits to places of employment, including a minimum
distance, as set forth in section 70 of the act, of fifteen feet (15') from
entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an
enclosed area where smoking is prohibited; trailers, offices, and work areas;
restrooms; conference rooms and classrooms; breakrooms and cafeterias; and
other common areas. A private residence or home based business, unless used to
provide licensed childcare, foster care, adult care, or other similar social
service care on the premises, is not a "place of employment", nor are enclosed
laboratories, not open to the public, in an accredited university or government
facility where the activity of smoking is exclusively conducted for the purpose
of medical or scientific health related research. For the purposes of this
chapter, any open air dining area, and the area within or under any tent,
canopy, trailer, and/or any other partially enclosed or partially covered
permanent or temporary structure shall be considered a "place of employment".
PRIVATE CLUB: A not for profit association that: a) has been in active and
continuous existence for at least three (3) years prior to January 1, 2008,
whether incorporated or not, b) is the owner, lessee, or occupant of a building
or portion thereof used exclusively for club purposes at all times, c) is
operated solely for a recreational, fraternal, social, patriotic, political,
benevolent, or athletic purpose, but not for pecuniary gain, and d) only sells
alcoholic beverages incidental to its operation. For purposes of this
definition, "private club" means an organization that is managed by a board of
directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at an
annual meeting, has established bylaws, a constitution, or both, to govern its
activities, and has been granted an exemption from the payment of federal
income tax as a club under 26 USC 501.
PRIVATE RESIDENCE: The part of a structure used as a dwelling, including,
without limitation, a private home, townhouse, condominium, apartment, mobile
home, vacation home, cabin, or cottage. For the purposes of this definition, a
hotel, motel, inn, resort, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public
accommodation, hospital, nursing home, or assisted living facility shall not be
considered a private residence.
PUBLIC PLACE: That portion of any building, vehicle, or open air dining area,
used by and open to the public, regardless of whether the building, open air
dining area, or vehicle is owned in whole or in part by private persons or
entities, the state of Illinois, or any other public entity and regardless of
whether a fee is charged for admission, including a minimum distance, as set
forth in section 70 of the act, of fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits,
windows that open, and ventilation intakes that serve an enclosed area where
smoking is prohibited. A "public place" does not include a private residence
unless the private residence is used to provide licensed childcare, foster
care, or other similar social service care on the premises. A "public place"
includes, but is not limited to, hospitals, restaurants, retail stores,
offices, commercial establishments, elevators, indoor theaters, libraries,
museums, concert halls, public conveyances, educational facilities, nursing
homes, auditoriums, enclosed or partially enclosed sports arenas, meeting
rooms, schools, exhibition halls, convention facilities, polling places,
private clubs, gaming facilities, tents, trailers, all government owned
vehicles and facilities, including buildings and vehicles owned, leased, or
operated by the village or by the state or state subcontract, healthcare
facilities or clinics, enclosed shopping centers, retail service
establishments, financial institutions, educational facilities, ticket areas,
public hearing facilities, public restrooms, waiting areas, lobbies, bars,
taverns, bowling alleys, skating rinks, reception areas, and no less than
seventy five percent (75%) of the sleeping quarters within a hotel, motel,
resort, inn, lodge, bed and breakfast, or other similar public accommodation
that are rented to guests, but excludes private residences. For the purposes of
this chapter, any open air dining area, and the area within or under any tent,
canopy, trailer, and/or any other partially enclosed or partially covered
permanent or temporary structure shall be considered a "public place".
RESTAURANT:
   A.   An eating establishment, including, but not limited to, coffee shops,
cafeterias, sandwich stands, and private and public school cafeterias, that
gives or offers for sale food to the public, guests, or employees, and
   B.   A kitchen or catering facility in which food is prepared on the
premises for serving elsewhere.
RETAIL TOBACCO STORE: A retail establishment that derives more than eighty
percent (80%) of its gross revenue from the sale of loose tobacco, plants, or
herbs and cigars, cigarettes, pipes, other smoking devices for burning tobacco
and related smoking accessories, and alternative nicotine products and in which
the sale of other products is merely incidental. "Retail tobacco store"
includes an enclosed workplace that manufactures, imports, or distributes
tobacco, tobacco products or alternative nicotine products, when, as a
necessary and integral part of the process of making, manufacturing, importing,
or distributing a tobacco product or alternative nicotine product for the
eventual retail sale of that tobacco, tobacco product, or alternative nicotine
product, tobacco is heated, burned, or smoked, or a lighted tobacco product or
alternative nicotine product is tested, provided that the involved business
entity: a) maintains a specially designated area or areas within the workplace
for the purpose of the heating, burning, smoking, or lighting activities, and
does not create a facility that permits smoking throughout; b) satisfies the
eighty percent (80%) requirement related to gross sales; and c) delivers
tobacco products or alternative nicotine products to consumers, retail
establishments, or other wholesale establishments as part of its business.
"Retail tobacco store" does not include a tobacco or alternative nicotine
product department or section of a larger commercial establishment or any
establishment with any type of liquor, food, or restaurant license.
SMOKE OR SMOKING: The carrying, smoking, burning, inhaling or exhaling of any
kind of lighted pipe, cigar, cigarette, hookah, weed, herbs, smoking herb(s)
(as defined in section 6-2-14 of this code) or any other lighted smoking
equipment, or the use, whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving,
inhaling, snorting, sniffing or by any other means, of alternative nicotine
product.
STATE: The state of Illinois.
VILLAGE: The village of Lake Villa, Lake County, Illinois. (Ord. 2015-03-01, 3-
11-2015)
4-10-4: SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES, PLACES OF EMPLOYMENT, AND IN OTHER LOCATIONS
PROHIBITED:
   A.   No person shall smoke in a public place or in any place of employment
or within fifteen feet (15') of any entrance to a public place or place of
employment.
   B.   No person may smoke in any vehicle located in the village owned,
leased, or operated by the village, by the state, or by any political
subdivision of the state.
   C.   Smoking is prohibited in indoor public places and workplaces unless
specifically exempted by this chapter.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke or to carry any form of
lighted cigar, cigarettes, pipe or tobacco or to use, whether by chewing,
smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting, sniffing or by any other
means, alternative nicotine product, in any building on village property.
   E.   An owner shall reasonably assure that smoking is prohibited by signage
specified in section 4-10-6 of this chapter within a minimum distance of
fifteen feet (15') from entrances, exits, windows that open, and ventilation
intakes that serve an enclosed area where smoking is prohibited under this
chapter so as to ensure that tobacco smoke does not enter the area through
entrances, exits, open windows, or other means.
   F.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, smoking is
prohibited in any portion of the living quarters, including, but not limited
to, sleeping rooms, dining areas, restrooms, laundry areas, lobbies, and
hallways, of a building used in whole or in part as a student dormitory that is
owned and operated or otherwise utilized by a public or private institution of
higher education. (Ord. 2015-03-01, 3-11-2015)
